questions.text: A 32 year male walked into OPD with unilateral throbbing pain, photophobia, watery eyes and severe stabbing pain on her left mandible. He complains the pain episodes last a few seconds and occur 20 times a day. Neurological examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following nerves is likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical symptoms draw diagnosis towards trigeminal neuralgia and hence the nerve Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal Nerve) particularly mandibular (V3) division.

  • This clinical picture is classic for trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux), a condition characterized by:
    • Recurrent brief episodes of sharp, stabbing, electric shock-like facial pain
    • Often triggered by activities like touching the face, chewing, or cold wind
    • Pain typically occurs in the V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) divisions
  • Mandibular region involvement suggests V3 branch.
  • Watery eyes and photophobia may be due to referred autonomic symptoms, often seen in trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias
  • The trigeminal nerve (CN V) is the main sensory nerve of the face, with:
    • V1: Ophthalmic (forehead, eye)
    • V2: Maxillary (cheek, upper jaw)
    • Mandibular (lower jaw, also motor to muscles of mastication)

choices.text: Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.text: Which of the following does not pass from the following structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is jugular foramen. The jugular foramen transmits the inferior petrosal sinus, spinal accessory nerve, and meningeal branch of the occipital artery, but not the meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery. (Options A , B , C ruled out)

The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery passes through foramen Lacerum.

questions.text: A patient presenting with dysphagia, loss of sensory function from posterior 1/3 of tongue, absent gag reflex and trapezius muscle paresis was diagnosed with Vernet syndrome. Which of the following structures passes through the posterior part of the involved foramen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Vernet syndrome, the lesion involves the jugular foramen, and the posterior part of this foramen transmits the sigmoid sinus, which drains into the internal jugular vein.

  • Vernet syndrome also known as Jugular foramen syndrome
  • Jugular foramen can be divided into three compartments:
    • Anterior - Inferior petrosal sinus (Option A ruled out)
    • Intermediate - CN 9,10,11 (Options B , C ruled out)
    • Posterior - sigmoid sinus continuing as the internal Jugular vein.
  • In Vernet syndrome (jugular foramen syndrome), there is:
    • Dysphagia (CN X)
    • Loss of taste/sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue (CN IX)
    • Absent gag reflex (CN IX and X)
    • Trapezius and SCM weakness (CN XI)
  • The sigmoid sinus, a continuation of the transverse sinus, travels through the posterior compartment of the foramen to form the internal jugular vein.

choices.text: Ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, heterochromia iridis, straight hair on one side
Bilateral ptosis, diplopia, fatigability, improved by rest
Fasciculations, spasticity, and hyperreflexia in limbs
Fluctuating limb weakness with preserved pupillary reflex

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is/are consistent with a lesion of the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure corresponds to the sympathetic chain, and its lesion results in features of congenital Horner syndrome, including ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, and heterochromia iridis due to disrupted sympathetic innervation during development.

  • Horner syndrome results from disruption of the oculosympathetic pathway.
  • In congenital Horner syndrome, sympathetic denervation occurs during early development, leading to:
    • Mild ptosis (loss of superior tarsal muscle tone)
    • Miosis (pupillary constriction due to unopposed parasympathetic activity)
    • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating)
    • Heterochromia iridis (due to decreased melanocyte stimulation on the affected side)
    • Unilateral straight hair (regional sympathetic loss affecting piloerection and hair texture)

questions.text: A patient underwent parotidectomy 2 weeks back, now complaining of sweating and flushing of skin over the cheek during mastication. Which nerve is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sweating and flushing of the cheek during mastication after parotidectomy indicates Frey's syndrome, which results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibers.

  • Frey's syndrome(also known as Baillarger's syndrome, Dupuy's syndrome, auriculotemporal syndrome, or Frey-Baillarger syndrome) is a rare neurological disorder resulting from damage to or near the parotid glands responsible for making saliva, and from damage to the auriculotemporal nerve often from surgery.
  • The symptoms of Frey's syndrome are redness and sweating on the cheek area adjacent to the ear (see focal hyperhidrosis).
  • They can appear when the affected person eats, sees, dreams, thinks about or talks about certain kinds of food which produce strong salivation.
  • Observing sweating in the region after eating a lemon wedge may be diagnostic.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3), carries:
    • Sensory fibers to the skin over the temple and anterior ear
    • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers from the otic ganglion to the parotid gland
  • In parotidectomy, post-surgical misdirection of parasympathetic fibers destined for the parotid gland may result in regeneration into nearby sweat glands and blood vessels of the skin. This causes:
    • Gustatory sweating (sweating during eating)
    • Flushing of the cheek skin
  • This phenomenon is known as Frey's syndrome (auriculotemporal nerve syndrome).

choices.text: The nerve lies on the anterior surface of the midbrain in the interpeduncular fossa
The nerve enters the superior orbital fissure through the common tendinous ring
The nerve passes to the middle cranial fossa along the lateral dural wall of the cavernous sinus
The nerve to inferior oblique carries parasympathetic fibers to the Otic ganglion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding palsy showing in image ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parasympathetic fibers destined for the ciliary ganglion are carried by the branch to inferior oblique, not by the nerve to inferior rectus

The image refers to oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) palsy, which causes:

  • Ptosis (levator palpebrae superioris paralysis)
  • 'Down and out' eye (unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique)
  • Mydriasis (loss of parasympathetic input to sphincter pupillae)

There are two structures in the eye that receive parasympathetic innervation from the oculomotor nerve:

  • Sphincter pupillae- constricts the pupil, reducing the amount of light entering the eye.
  • Ciliary muscles- contracts, causes the lens to become more spherical, and thus more adapted to short range vision.

The preganglionic parasympathetic fibres travel in the inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve. Within the orbit, they branch off and synapse in the ciliary ganglion. The post-ganglionic fibres are carried to the eye via the short ciliary nerves.

  • Anatomical pathway of the oculomotor nerve:
    • Emerges from anterior midbrain in the interpeduncular fossa (Option A ruled out)
    • Runs between posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries
    • Pierces dura to enter the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus (Option C ruled out)
    • Enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure through the common tendinous ring (Option B ruled out)
    • Divides into superior and inferior divisions:
      • Inferior division → gives branch to inferior oblique, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves carries parasympathetic fibers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cranial nerves carrying parasympathetic fibers are listed below:

  • Cranial nerve. Associated Ganglia
  • Oculomotor (Ill) Ciliary ganglion
  • Facial (VII). Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglion
  • Glossopharyngeal(IX) Otic ganglion
  • Vagus (X) Visceral ganglions

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy fell from a building and was rushed to the emergency department. CT scan reveals a skull base fracture involving the apex of the petrous temporal bone, affecting a space bounded by the petrous apex, clivus, and the petroclinoid ligament. Which of the following cranial nerves is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) runs through a narrow, fixed space at the petrous apex and clivus under the petroclinoid ligament, making it highly vulnerable to injury in petrous bone fractures. This area is known as Dorello's canal.

  • The abducens nerve (CN VI) has a long and tortuous intracranial course:
    • It emerges from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction.
    • It ascends and enters a fibro-osseous canal at the petrous apex, bounded by the petrous part of temporal bone, clivus, and the petroclinoid ligament (historically known as Dorello's canal).
    • Then it enters the cavernous sinus, where it lies medially and most vulnerable among cranial nerves.
    • Finally, it enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure, innervating the lateral rectus muscle.
  • In skull base fractures, especially involving the petrous apex, the abducens nerve is at high risk due to its tight confinement within this canal, making it susceptible to stretch or compression injury, causing lateral gaze palsy.

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) (Option B) : Exits the skull via the jugular foramen, located posterior and lateral, not near the petrous apex.

Trochlear nerve (CN IV) (Option C) : Although it travels near the tentorium, it does not pass through the petrous apex region or that confined canal.

Vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) (Option D) : Traverses the internal acoustic meatus, which lies more laterally in the petrous bone, not near the clivus or petroclinoid ligament.

choices.text: Visceral Efferent > Visceral Afferent >Somatic Afferent > Somatic Efferent
Visceral Efferent > Somatic Efferent >Visceral Afferent > Somatic Afferent
Somatic Afferent > Visceral Afferent >Visceral Efferent > Somatic Efferent
Somatic Efferent > Visceral Afferent >Visceral Efferent > Somatic Afferent

questions.text: The arrangement of the functional columns of cranial nerve nuclei from ventral to dorsal aspect in the brainstem is as follows:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The organization of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem follows a dorsal-to-ventral arrangement of afferents and efferents, with somatic afferent nuclei most dorsal and somatic efferent nuclei most ventral.

  • In the embryological development of the neural tube, particularly in the brainstem, the alar plate (sensory) lies dorsally, and the basal plate (motor) lies ventrally.
  • These give rise to functional columns of cranial nerve nuclei, arranged from dorsal to ventral as follows:
    • Afferent (Sensory) Columns - Dorsally placed:
      • Somatic Afferent (SA) - Somatic sensory (e.g., trigeminal sensory nucleus)
      • Visceral Afferent (VA) - Visceral sensory (e.g., nucleus tractus solitarius)
    • Efferent (Motor) Columns - Ventrally placed:
      • Visceral Efferent (VE) - Autonomic motor (e.g., dorsal motor nucleus of vagus)
      • Somatic Efferent (SE) - Somatic motor (e.g., hypoglossal nucleus)
    • This arrangement is preserved in the floor of the fourth ventricle, particularly in the pons and medulla, and helps localize lesions based on clinical presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei do not belong to the special visceral efferent (SVE) column?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus supplies general visceral efferent (GVE) fibers (autonomic), whereas the special visceral efferent (SVE) column innervates muscles derived from pharyngeal (branchial) arches.

The Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) column supplies striated skeletal muscles derived from the pharyngeal (branchial) arches, such as muscles of mastication, facial expression, pharynx, larynx, and parts of the soft palate.

  • Nuclei that belong to the SVE column:
  • Not part of SVE:
    • Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus (CN X):
      • Belongs to General Visceral Efferent (GVE)
      • Supplies parasympathetic fibers to thoracic and abdominal viscera
      • No relation to pharyngeal arch-derived skeletal muscles

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the marked foramen ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The foramen marked on the CT scan is the mandibular foramen on the medial surface of the ramus of the mandible, which transmits the inferior alveolar nerve.

  • The inferior alveolar nerve is a mandibular nerve branch.
  • The inferior alveolar nerve is responsible for sensory innervation to the gingivae on the lower jaw.
  • The inferior alveolar nerve also branches into the mylohyoid nerve and the mental nerve. 
  • As the inferior alveolar nerve descends the mandible, it will branch into the mylohyoid nerve to provide motor innervation to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • The inferior alveolar nerve will then travel in the mandibular foramen until it reaches the mental foramen.
  • Once at the mental foramen, the inferior alveolar nerve exits and becomes the mental nerve.
  • The mental nerve is responsible for innervating the chin, lower lip, and gingivae.
  • This foramen is commonly visualized on axial CT and is clinically important for inferior alveolar nerve blocks in dental procedures.

Explanation of other options:

Lingual nerve (Option A) : Passes anterior to the mandibular foramen and enters the oral cavity; it does not enter the mandibular canal.

Chorda tympani nerve (Option C) : Joins the lingual nerve and carries taste fibers to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue but does not pass through the mandibular foramen.

Zygomatic nerve (Option D) : Branch of the maxillary nerve (V2); passes through the inferior orbital fissure and zygomatic bone, not the mandibular foramen.

questions.text: A person presents with bleeding, infection, swollen jaw and facial drooping after undergoing Botox procedure 3 days back. On further inquiry it is found that the patient is injected with Botulinum toxin type A into the submandibular gland. Which of the following nerves has undergone aberrant innervation in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The auriculotemporal nerve carries postganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the otic ganglion to the submandibular gland, and botulinum toxin injection into the gland can affect this nerve.

  • The submandibular gland receives parasympathetic innervation primarily from the facial nerve via chorda tympani, which joins the lingual nerve to reach the submandibular ganglion, and not from the auriculotemporal nerve directly.
  • However, in some anatomical variants or due to iatrogenic aberrant connections, especially post-surgical or post-inflammatory, postganglionic fibers from the otic ganglion (via auriculotemporal nerve) may aberrantly innervate the submandibular gland.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), normally carries secretomotor fibers from the otic ganglion to the parotid gland, but in rare cases, it may abnormally innervate the submandibular gland, especially in post-traumatic or surgically altered anatomy.
  • Injection of Botulinum toxin into the submandibular gland in such cases can disrupt the aberrant autonomic pathway, resulting in symptoms like facial drooping, infection, and jaw swelling due to spread to neighboring structures or neural compromise.

choices.text: Sternal head of right and left sterncleidomastoid

questions.text: A 54 year old female was referred to hospital for managing bilateral vocal cord palsy after thyroidectomy with airway difficulties. She underwent neck dissection and Pathology revealed three metastatic lymph nodes between the Sternocleidomastoid and Sternohyoid muscles (LNSS). Surgical view of the metastatic lymph node (white arrow) between the right sternocleidomastoid and sternohyoid muscles (LNSS) is as follows.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The supraclavicular nerve lies inferior to the region between the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and sternohyoid muscles, and is therefore not involved in the lymph node of the sternohyoid-sternocleidomastoid (LNSS) space.

  • LNSS (Lymph Node between Sternocleidomastoid and Sternohyoid muscles) is a rare but surgically important lymph node located deep to the sternohyoid muscle and anterior to the internal jugular vein, often exposed during neck dissection for thyroid malignancy.
  • Structures in proximity to LNSS and commonly seen during surgery:
    • Sternal heads of right and left SCM: Form the lateral boundaries of the space.
    • Anterior jugular vein: Often traverses this space, important to preserve or manage during surgery.
    • Interclavicular ligament: Fibrous band connecting sternal heads at the lower neck, anterior to LNSS.
  • The supraclavicular nerve, a cutaneous branch of the cervical plexus (C3–C4), runs superficially across the clavicle, supplying skin over the shoulder and upper chest , not in the deep anterior triangle where LNSS is located.

Explanation of other options:

Interclavicular ligament (Option B) : It lies superior to the manubrium, between the SCMs , relevant in neck dissection near LNSS.

Anterior jugular vein (Option C) : Courses just anterior to or in the same plane as LNSS, often encountered in surgeries for thyroid or lymph node clearance.

Sternal head of right and left sternocleidomastoid (Option D) : These form the lateral boundaries of the space where LNSS resides.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the branch of artery given below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked arrow is showing facial artery. All options except the premasseteric artery are branches of the facial artery, whereas the premasseteric artery is a branch of the maxillary artery.

  • The facial artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, courses through the submandibular gland, curves over the mandible, and supplies the superficial face.
  • Branches of the facial artery include:
    • Ascending palatine artery – supplies soft palate and palatine tonsil. (Option B ruled out)
    • Tonsillar artery – pierces the superior constrictor to supply the palatine tonsil. (Option D ruled out)
    • Submental artery – largest cervical branch, supplies the submental region and adjacent muscles. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following components passes through the inferomedial compartment of the given structure ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is Superior orbital fissure and Inferior ophthalmic vein passes through it.

The components of superior orbital fissure is as follows :

Above the common tendinous ring: (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior ophthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring: (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

Explanation of other options:

Superior ophthalmic vein (Option B) :Passes through the superolateral part of the superior orbital fissure, outside the inferomedial compartment.

Nasociliary nerve (Option C) : Passes through the superomedial compartment of the superior orbital fissure, not the inferomedial part.

Lacrimal nerve (Option D) : Travels through the lateral compartment of the superior orbital fissure, lateral to the nasociliary nerve and not in the inferomedial compartment.

choices.text: Superior Ophthalmic and inferior Ophthalmic vein
Inferior Ophthalmic and Deep facial veins
Deep facial and superior facial veins

questions.text: The blood from the given area drains through the facial vein with the pterygoid venous plexus through which of the following veins ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The blood from the Danger area drains through the facial vein which connects to the pterygoid venous plexus through the deep facial vein and indirectly through the inferior ophthalmic vein.

  • The facial vein forms an important connection between the superficial and deep venous systems.
  • It drains the danger area of the face (nose, upper lip, and surrounding area), which can potentially spread infections to the cavernous sinus through:
    • Deep facial vein that connects facial vein to the pterygoid venous plexus
    • Inferior ophthalmic vein that drains into the superior ophthalmic vein, which continues to the cavernous sinus
  • These connections are valveless, allowing retrograde flow, which can transmit infection from superficial face to the intracranial venous sinuses, leading to cavernous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries supplies the gland shown below ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Parathyroid gland that receives its blood supply from inferior thyroid artery , a branch of subclavian artery

  • The thyroid gland has a rich blood supply from three main sources:
    • Superior thyroid artery - a branch of the external carotid artery, supplying the upper pole.
    • Inferior thyroid artery - arises from the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery, and supplies the posteroinferior part of the gland.

Thyroid ima artery - a variable artery (present in ~10%) that may arise from the brachiocephalic trunk, aortic arch, or common carotid and supply the isthmus

Explanation:

The correct matches are based on unique anatomical features of each cranial nerve—length, emergence, and projection pathways.

  • Vagus nerve (CN X) → Longest extracranial course (d): It travels from the brainstem to the thoracoabdominal viscera.
  • Facial nerve (CN VII) → Longest intraosseous course (c): It traverses the facial canal in the temporal bone before emerging at the stylomastoid foramen.
  • Olfactory nerve (CN I) → Direct projection to cerebral cortex (a): It projects directly to the olfactory cortex without relaying through the thalamus.
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV) → Dorsal aspect of brainstem (b): It is the only cranial nerve to emerge dorsally from the brainstem and decussate.

One-liners to remember:

  • Smallest Cranial Nerve→ Trochlear.
  • Largest Cranial Nerve→ Trigeminal.
  • Thickest Cranial Nerve→ Trigeminal.
  • Longest Cranial Nerve→ Vagus.
  • Sensory Cranial Nerves→ CN 1, 2, 8.
  • Motor Cranial Nerves→ CN 3, 4, 6, 11, 12.
  • Nerve passing between PCA and Sup cerebellar artery→ 3rd nerve
  • Mixed Sensory & Motor CN→ CN 5, 7, 9, 10.
  • Cranial Nerve Emerging From Dorsal Aspect of Brainstem → Trochlear.
  • Cranial Nerve with Direct Projection to Cerebral Cortex→ Olfactory.
  • Cranial Nerve with Longest Intracranial Course→ Trochlear.
  • Cranial Nerve with Longest Extracranial Course→ Vagus.
  • Cranial Nerve with Longest Intraosseous Course→ Facial.
  • Cranial Nerve Affected in Pyogenic Meningitis→ CN VIlI.
  • Cranial Nerve Affected in Tuberculous Meningitis→ CN III.
  • Cranial Nerve Affected in Multiple Sclerosis→ Optic Nerve.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department with knife lacerations to the face. One laceration is a deep wound to the superior aspect of the chin. Identify the artery most likely damaged by this lesion.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mental artery emerges from the mental foramen and supplies the chin and lower lip, making it the most likely vessel injured in a deep chin laceration.

  • The mental artery is a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which exits the mental foramen (located on the anterior surface of the mandible) to supply the skin of the chin, lower lip, and vestibular gingiva of the anterior teeth.
  • A deep wound over the superior aspect of the chin is most likely to injure this artery.

Explanation of other options:

Angular artery (Option A): It is a terminal branch of the facial artery and supplies the medial angle of the eye and upper cheek, not the chin.

Superior labial artery (Option B): It supplies the upper lip and nasal septum, not the lower lip or chin region.

Transverse facial artery (Option C): It is a branch of the superficial temporal artery and runs above the parotid duct, supplying the cheek, not the chin.

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the upper lip
Ability to forcefully close the eyes is diminished
Loss of sensation in the tip of the tongue

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fractured mandible after a bar fight. After the mandibular reconstruction surgery, the patient is noted to have loss of sensation in his lower lip. After further testing, it is determined that the patient has damage to the mandibular branch of his trigeminal nerve. Which of the following symptoms would also likely fit this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mandibular branch (V3) of the trigeminal nerve supplies general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via the lingual nerve, making this symptom consistent with V3 injury.

  • The mandibular nerve (V3), a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), carries both sensory and motor fibers.
    • Sensory branches of V3 include:
      • Mental nerve (to lower lip and chin via inferior alveolar)
      • Buccal nerve
      • Auriculotemporal nerve
      • Lingual nerve (to anterior 2/3 of tongue – general sensation only)
    • Damage to V3 (especially inferior alveolar or lingual branches) can cause:
      • Numbness in the lower lip and chin
      • Loss of general (not taste) sensation to the anterior 2/3 of tongue

Explanation of other options:

Loss of sensation of the upper lip (Option A): Supplied by the infraorbital nerve, a branch of maxillary nerve (V2), not V3.

Ability to swallow is diminished (Option B): This involves CN IX (glossopharyngeal) and CN X (vagus), not CN V.

Ability to forcefully close the eyes is diminished (Option C): This is a function of the orbicularis oculi muscle, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), not the trigeminal nerve.

choices.text: At the level of the ascending pharyngeal artery
At the level of the occipital artery

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents with symptoms suggestive of reduced perfusion to the right side of his face. Clinical examination reveals absent pulses in the facial artery, posterior auricular artery, superficial temporal artery, occipital artery, and maxillary artery territory, all on the right side. However, no ischemic symptoms are noted in the pharynx or deep cervical region, and the ascending pharyngeal artery appears unaffected.
Which of the following best describes the level of occlusion in the external carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The absence of blood flow in all distal branches except the ascending pharyngeal artery indicates the thrombus is just distal to the ascending pharyngeal and just below the facial artery origin.

The external carotid artery (ECA) gives off eight branches. In order from inferior to superior:

  • Superior thyroid artery
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Lingual artery
  • Facial artery
  • Occipital artery
  • Posterior auricular artery
  • Maxillary artery
  • Superficial temporal artery

choices.text: Inability to wrinkle the forehead on the left side
Drooping of the left corner of the mouth when smiling
Inability to close the left eyelid tightly
Deviation of the tongue to the left on protrusion

questions.text: An 83-year-old man suffers a stroke involving the left facial motor nucleus in the pons, resulting in lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve palsy on the left side. Which of the following motor deficits is he least likely to experience?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tongue deviation is mediated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), not the facial nerve; hence, this is not expected in isolated facial nerve palsy.

  • A lesion of the facial motor nucleus causes ipsilateral LMN type facial palsy, leading to:
    • Paralysis of both upper and lower facial muscles on the same side (here, left).
    • Involvement includes inability to close eyelids, wrinkle forehead, or smile on the affected side.
  • The tongue is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII).
  • Tongue deviation occurs in hypoglossal nerve palsy, not in facial nerve involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Inability to wrinkle the forehead on the left side (Option A) : LMN lesion affects both upper and lower face, so forehead paralysis is expected.

Drooping of the left corner of the mouth when smiling (Option B) : This is a typical LMN facial palsy feature - drooping of the mouth on the same side as the lesion.

Inability to close the left eyelid tightly (Option C) : Orbicularis oculi (for eyelid closure) is paralyzed in LMN palsy - expected.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the parotid gland are correct?
1. The parotid gland is enclosed within a tough capsule derived from the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.
2. The facial artery passes through the substance of the parotid gland along with the retromandibular vein and facial nerve.
3. The external surface of the parotid gland is innervated by the great auricular nerve, while secretomotor innervation comes from the glossopharyngeal nerve via the otic ganglion.
4. The superficial boundary of the parotid gland is formed by the masseter muscle, while the deep boundary is related to the styloid process.
5. The facial nerve divides into its terminal branches within the parotid gland but does not innervate the gland.
Choose the correct combination:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The facial artery does not pass through the parotid gland; only the external carotid artery, retromandibular vein, and facial nerve do.

The superficial surface of the gland lies against skin and fascia, not the masseter. The anteromedial boundary relates to the masseter, and the deep part lies against the styloid process.

Parotid Gland - Anatomy

  • General Features
    • The parotid gland is the largest salivary gland.
    • It is purely serous and located in the parotid region, anterior inferior to the external acoustic meatus, between the mandible and the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM).
  • Boundaries of the Parotid Gland
  • Facial Capsule
    • Enclosed by the parotid fascia, derived from the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.
    • Very dense and unyielding, which is why parotitis is painful (swelling within a tough capsule).
  • Contents of the Parotid Gland
    • Facial nerve (CN VII) - divides into 5 terminal branches:
      • Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Mandibular (Marginal), Cervical
    • Retromandibular vein
    • External carotid artery (gives terminal branches within gland):
      • Maxillary artery
      • Superficial temporal artery
    • The facial artery does NOT pass through the gland - it passes deep to it.
  • Duct - Stensen's Duct
    • Emerges from anterior border, crosses masseter, pierces buccinator, opens into the oral vestibule opposite the 2nd upper molar.
  • Blood Supply
    • Arterial: External carotid artery and its branches.
    • Venous drainage: Retromandibular vein.
  • Lymphatic Drainage
    • Superficial and deep parotid lymph nodes → deep cervical nodes
  • Nerve Supply
    • Sensory (Capsule) : Great auricular nerve (C2-C3)
    • Parasympathetic : Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) via otic ganglion → auriculotemporal nerve (V3)
    • Sympathetic : Plexus around external carotid artery (vasomotor)
  • Applied Anatomy
    • Parotitis (e.g., mumps): Swelling is painful due to a tough capsule.
    • Parotidectomy: Facial nerves must be identified and preserved.
    • Frey’s Syndrome (Gustatory sweating): Aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve after surgery.

choices.text: Paralysis of the facial muscles and loss of taste.
Paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste and lacrimation.
Paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste, lacrimation and decreased salivation.

questions.text: A lesion causing compression of the facial nerve at the stylomastoid foramen will cause ipsilateral
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A lesion at the stylomastoid foramen affects only the motor branches of the facial nerve, causing ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis, without affecting taste, lacrimation, or salivation.

The facial nerve arises from the brainstem (pontomedullary junction) and has the following segments:

  • Intracranial: From the brainstem to the internal acoustic meatus.
  • Intratemporal: Within the facial canal (in the petrous part of the temporal bone).
  • Extracranial: Emerges through stylomastoid foramen, then enters the parotid gland and divides into terminal branches.

Important Branches of Facial Nerve:

Key Takeaways:

LMN facial nerve lesion at the stylomastoid foramen causes complete ipsilateral facial paralysis, including forehead, unlike UMN lesions, which spare the forehead due to bilateral cortical input.

Explanation of other options:

Paralysis of the facial muscles and loss of taste (Option B): The chorda tympani nerve, which carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, branches off the facial nerve within the facial canal (before it exits the stylomastoid foramen), so taste remains intact in lesions at or after the foramen.

Paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste and lacrimation (Option C): The greater petrosal nerve, which mediates lacrimation via the pterygopalatine ganglion, also branches before the facial nerve exits the stylomastoid foramen. Hence, lacrimation is unaffected in such a lesion.

Paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste, lacrimation and decreased salivation (Option D): Salivation to submandibular and sublingual glands is via parasympathetic fibers in the chorda tympani, which exits earlier in the facial canal. Therefore, salivation is also preserved. This option includes all functions, most of which are unaffected by a lesion limited to the stylomastoid foramen.

questions.text: Which of these branches of the trigeminal nerve contain somatic motor processes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The three branches given are the major cutaneous sensory branches of the ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular divisions of the trigeminal nerve respectively which are all sensory nerves.

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) is primarily a sensory nerve, but its mandibular division (V3) also carries somatic motor fibers to muscles of mastication and a few others.

  • Trigeminal Divisions:
  • The motor fibers of CN V3 supply:
    • Muscles of mastication: masseter, temporalis, medial/lateral pterygoid
    • Mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric
    • Tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini

Explanation of other options:

The supraorbital nerve (Option A) : Branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) - purely sensory to forehead and scalp.

The infraorbital nerve (Option B) : Branch of the maxillary division (V2) - purely sensory to midface, lower eyelid, upper lip.

The mental nerve (Option C) : Terminal sensory branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (from V3) - supplies chin and lower lip but carries no motor fibers.

choices.text: Deep to masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second molar.
Superficial to masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second molar.
Deep to masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second premolar.
Superficial to masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second premolar.

questions.text: The parotid duct runs along
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The parotid duct (Stensen’s duct) passes superficial to the masseter, pierces the buccinator muscle, and opens into the oral cavity opposite the upper second molar tooth.

  • The parotid duct is about 5 cm long and originates from the anterior border of the parotid gland.
  • Course:
    • Runs horizontally forward, superficial to the masseter muscle.
    • At the anterior edge of the masseter, it turns medially.
    • Pierces the buccal fat pad, buccopharyngeal fascia, and buccinator muscle.
    • Opens into the vestibule of the mouth, opposite the crown of the upper 2nd maxillary molar.
  • The buccinator muscle prevents the duct from ballooning during secretion by acting as a muscular valve.

Explanation of other options:

Deep to the masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second molar (Option A): The duct runs superficial, not deep, to the masseter muscle.

Deep to the masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second premolar (Option C): Incorrect tooth location and incorrect relation to masseter.

Superficial to masseter and enters the mouth opposite the upper second premolar (Option D): Although relation to masseter is correct, the duct opens opposite the second molar, not premolar.

questions.text: A woman suffering from severe headaches and neck stiffness is seen by her physician. Neurologic evaluation reveals that her uvula deviates to the right upon elevation of the palate. Which nerve is most likely affected by the tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deviation of the uvula to the right indicates a left-sided vagus nerve lesion, as the levator veli palatini on the left is paralyzed, and the intact right side pulls the uvula toward it.

  • The vagus nerve (CN X) provides motor innervation to the muscles of the soft palate (except tensor veli palatini) via the pharyngeal plexus.
  • The most important muscle here is the levator veli palatini, which elevates the soft palate during phonation and swallowing.
  • If there is a lesion of the left vagus nerve, the left side of the soft palate fails to elevate.
  • As a result, the right side pulls the uvula toward the unaffected side. Hence, uvula deviates to the right.

Rule of 17 explains -

In UMN (upper motor neuron) lesions (e.g., stroke):

  • Lower face is contralaterally paralyzed
  • Upper face is spared due to bilateral cortical innervation

In LMN (lower motor neuron) lesions (e.g., Bell's palsy):

  • Both upper and lower parts of the ipsilateral face are paralyzed

Explanation of other options:

Left glossopharyngeal (Option A): The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is primarily sensory to the oropharynx and posterior tongue and contributes to the gag reflex, not uvula movement.

Right glossopharyngeal (Option C): As above, CN IX does not innervate palatal muscles or control uvula deviation.

Right hypoglossal (Option D): The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) controls tongue movements. Lesions cause tongue deviation, not uvular deviation.

Key Takeaways:

Uvula deviates away from the side of a vagus nerve lesion (because the intact side pulls more), while tongue deviates toward the side of a hypoglossal nerve lesion (because the weak side can’t oppose).

choices.text: Only motor function of facial expression is lost, while lacrimation and taste are preserved.
Lacrimation may be impaired due to involvement of the greater petrosal nerve.
Smell sensation is lost due to involvement of the chorda tympani.
General sensation from the face is affected due to trigeminal nerve involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding a lesion of the facial nerve proximal to the geniculate ganglion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A facial nerve lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion affects all branches distal to that point, including the greater petrosal nerve, which is responsible for lacrimation.

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction and enters the internal acoustic meatus, then traverses the facial canal within the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • At the geniculate ganglion, the facial nerve gives off:
    • Greater petrosal nerve (carries parasympathetic fibers for lacrimation via the pterygopalatine ganglion)
  • Distal to the ganglion:
    • Nerve to stapedius
    • Chorda tympani (taste + salivation) (Option C ruled out)
    • Terminal motor branches (facial expression)
  • Thus, a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion impairs:
    • Lacrimation (Option A ruled out)
    • Taste (anterior 2/3rd of tongue)
    • Salivation (submandibular/sublingual glands)
    • Motor to facial muscles (Option D ruled out)
    • Hyperacusis (due to stapedius paralysis)
